title: Europe needs to listen to the unusual suspects - E3G
summary: The article discusses Europe's urgent need to accelerate its transition to a net-zero economy, highlighting the importance of involving citizens and new voices in energy policy discussions to foster innovation and investment in clean technology. It emphasizes the need for a constructive and optimistic approach, leveraging Europe's unique strengths such as renewable energy resources and technological leadership while addressing social equity in the transition process. The call for a comprehensive, European-wide industrial policy to support this transition reflects a recognition that slow progress is not an option for addressing climate change and securing economic stability.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article outlines a transition to a clean technology economy and emphasizes sustainable energy policies, which contribute to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article references the need for new and improved products and processes to address the transition to a net-zero economy, indicating an evolution in business practices aimed at sustainability.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not provide specific examples of goods or services that meet the comprehensive definition of a green product.
green_process: FALSE - While it discusses the need for innovative clean technology processes, it does not specify any particular process that fits the definition of a green process.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 221118 - Other Electric Power Generation, 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology), 335999 - All Other Miscellaneous Electrical Equipment and Component Manufacturing, 926120 - Administration of Urban Planning and Community and Rural Development
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not make misleading claims about environmental benefits but advocates for genuine action and investment in clean technology, contrasting with the concept of greenwashing.

title: Cosmetic 360: “The green transition is an innovation challenge” - Premium beauty
summary: The Cosmetic 360 show focuses on the green transition in the cosmetics industry, highlighting technologies related to decarbonation, waste management, and sustainable practices. It features sessions on responsible consumption, eco-responsible packaging, and biosourced ingredients, alongside innovations from major players. The event aims to showcase clean technology solutions and promote networking around sustainable development. This year marks significant participation, with 250 exhibitors and plans for its 10th anniversary.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the event promotes technologies and practices that contribute to environmental sustainability in the cosmetics industry.
business_innovation: TRUE, because it highlights new products and processes in the cosmetics industry that significantly differ from previous offerings, contributing to industry progress.
green_product: FALSE, as the article details an event rather than a specific good or service designed to reduce environmental impact.
green_process: FALSE, as the article discusses an event focused on innovations, but does not name specific processes that minimize environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325620 - Toilet Paper Manufacturing, 339114 - Dental Equipment and Supplies Manufacturing, 325611 - Soap and Other Detergent Manufacturing, 424210 - Drugs and Druggists' Sundries Merchant Wholesalers
greenwashing: FALSE, as the event genuinely focuses on promoting sustainable practices and technologies in the cosmetics industry rather than misleading consumers about environmental benefits.

title: Government of Canada announces $9.9 million to scale up B.C. technology businesses and improve productivity - Canada NewsWire
summary: The Integrated Marketplace in British Columbia connects local tech companies with larger organizations to pilot green solutions, supported by $9.9 million in funding from the Government of Canada. This initiative aims to enhance the development and commercialization of clean technologies in practical environments like seaports and airports, contributing to decarbonization and improved efficiency. It serves to de-risk technology adoption while accelerating the growth of British Columbia's tech sector in clean technology. The program is also expected to foster job creation and position Canada as a leader in cleantech.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the Integrated Marketplace promotes the development and implementation of innovative technologies that aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and advance climate goals.
business_innovation: TRUE, because the initiative involves creating new processes and technologies to solve business challenges associated with sustainability and market demands.
green_product: FALSE, as the article does not specifically mention a particular green product; it discusses a program facilitating the testing and deployment of green technologies.
green_process: TRUE, because the integrated marketplace facilitates the development of sustainable operational processes, such as optimizing supply chains and electrifying support vehicles, which minimize environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology); 541511 - Custom Computer Programming Services; 488510 - Freight Transportation Arrangement; 924120 - Environmental Quality Consulting Services
greenwashing: FALSE, as the article does not contain misleading information about the environmental benefits of a product or practice; instead, it clearly outlines a genuine initiative aimed at promoting sustainable innovations.

title: Elemis partners with Morro to create upcycled single-use sachets for cosmetics - Premium beauty
summary: Elemis is collaborating with Morro to upcycle leftover plant waste into bio-based films to create plastic-free single-use sachets for cosmetic products. This initiative aims to address packaging dilemmas and the cosmetic industry's reliance on plastic. The project is supported by a grant and reflects Elemis's commitment to sustainable packaging by 2025. Xampla emphasizes that this innovation has significant potential to replace traditional plastic sachets with environmentally friendly alternatives.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because it involves upcycling plant waste into sustainable packaging solutions that minimize environmental impact by reducing plastic use.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation as it introduces a new and improved process for creating skincare product packaging that differs significantly from previous methods.
green_product: FALSE: The product is not clearly identified yet as it involves ongoing development and research.
green_process: TRUE: This is a green process as it utilizes waste materials from plants to create a new method of production that minimizes environmental impact and promotes sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325 cosmetics manufacturing, 326 plastics product manufacturing, 541710 research and development in the physical, engineering, and life sciences, 325120 plastics manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not describe greenwashing since it discusses a genuine commitment to developing sustainable packaging solutions, supported by research and collaboration.

title: CICE Funds Innovation to Advance the Measuring, Monitoring, and Verification (MMV) of Carbon Management - Canada NewsWire
summary: The B.C. Centre for Innovation and Clean Energy (CICE) has announced $2.82 million in funding for B.C. clean energy innovators working on measurement, monitoring, and verification (MMV) technologies that assist in carbon emission reduction, removal, and avoidance. The funded projects include technologies that focus on carbon mineralization, soil quality testing, and tracking carbon sequestration in forests. This funding aims to establish commercial pathways for these innovative solutions, potentially boosting the global carbon credit market and supporting CleanBC goals. The initiative underscores B.C.'s commitment to be a leader in clean technology and a low-carbon economy.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article describes funding for innovative technologies that support carbon emission reduction, which aligns with the goals of environmental sustainability and decarbonization.
business_innovation: TRUE: The article discusses new and improved processes and technologies introduced to the market by the companies receiving funding, which meet the definition of business innovation.
green_product: FALSE: The article focuses on technologies and processes rather than specific goods or services defined as green products.
green_process: TRUE: The article mentions innovative processes for measuring and verifying carbon emissions, which are designed to minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
